channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: A Chinese spy hired a private investigator to use violence if necessary to end a candidate’s run for U.S. Congress, instructing him to “beat him until he cannot run for election,” prosecutors alleged as they unsealed a series of complaints https://t.co/HqOQuzycaz

A deepfake video purporting to show Ukraine’s president issuing a statement he didn't make has been removed from Facebook and Instagram, Meta's head of security policy said Wednesday https://t.co/cZYyHfFl2s
Starbucks, iPhones and Ikea became part of urban Russians' daily life. Some worry things will never be the same. “Now, my children will live in the new old Soviet Union." https://t.co/Ay8OlU0MYq
Two members of Congress are seeking to formally honor journalists who have been injured or killed since Russia invaded Ukraine https://t.co/lybYcmyO6x
Vladimir Putin acknowledged that the Russian economy was hit hard by sanctions but says the West’s “economic blitzkrieg” had failed https://t.co/0zCPR90OTD
President Biden said he thinks Russian President Vladimir Putin is a war criminal, an escalation of his rhetoric as Moscow continues its attack in Ukraine https://t.co/dpfjj9jp7c

Attorney General Merrick Garland directed federal agencies to “apply a presumption of openness” when fulfilling Freedom of Information Act requests, as the denial rate for such inquiries has risen in recent years https://t.co/weRlijgmeQ
Italian police on Wednesday seized real estate and vehicles owned by two sanctioned Russian oligarchs, including mining magnate Alisher Usmanov https://t.co/YbU3bMZrPB

President Biden said the U.S. will send an additional $800 million in security assistance to Ukraine as the country tries to fend off Russia’s invasion, including 800 anti-aircraft systems to help defend its airspace https://t.co/TlDeDuOBut

China and Russia have often been contentious rivals, but under Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin, the two countries’ relations have grown closer. Here is a look at the tensions over China’s entente with Russia and what it could mean for the U.S. https://t.co/VnVH6Tyd4M

McDonald's, Levi's and other U.S. brands flooded into Russia in the 1990s. The attack on Ukraine looks to some like a death knell for the relationship. “It’s certainly the end of an era." https://t.co/h6kxFddvco

The Russian government has a big set of interest payments due to foreign bondholders on Wednesday, setting the stage for a potential default #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/vylaV9Q3PF https://t.co/oKQUQoytvr

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the U.S. to put in place a no-fly zone. "Russia has turned the Ukrainian sky into a source of death," he said in an emotional address to Congress. https://t.co/4imi3a5LOd
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/aVnMOM3fbx https://t.co/gNTFyslzX6
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will speak directly to the U.S. Congress in a virtual address, where he is expected to ask for more military aid. Watch live. https://t.co/zQGYQqsBHI
With NATO on high alert for Russian incursions into alliance territory, Ukraine’s military said it downed a Russian drone that had crossed into Polish airspace https://t.co/McfsIpJBoM
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is visiting the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia to deliver a plea from the West: pump more oil https://t.co/UpH9K4ij7j
Ukraine said it launched a counteroffensive against Russian forces encroaching on Kyiv and other key cities, seeking to reverse the momentum of the war https://t.co/0w12uvmIyQ
Odessa-based programmer Wang Jixian challenges Chinese fans of Vladimir Putin to put words into action on the battlefield, attracting millions of views https://t.co/PO2opNSEAZ
A year ago, China’s Xi Jinping appeared unassailable. Since then, thin cracks have emerged in his power. https://t.co/zZCHbfMUiZ
The woman who burst onto the set of Russia’s most-watched news program Monday evening with an antiwar poster was fined for protest violation https://t.co/YLcMkGYNyt
A year ago, China’s Xi Jinping appeared unassailable. Since then, thin cracks have emerged in his power. https://t.co/lQFRlhHAeK

From @WSJopinion: The Fed is supposed to have the world’s smartest economists and access to the best financial information. How could they make the greatest monetary policy mistake since the 1970s? https://t.co/4UGqAzUulr
Saudi Arabia is in talks to price its oil sales to China in yuan, people familiar with the matter said. The move would dent the U.S. dollar's dominance of the oil market. https://t.co/vXULohStxJ
The effort to make daylight-saving time a permanent fixture got a boost after senators unanimously passed the Sunshine Protection Act Tuesday. It now heads to the House. https://t.co/IJohKXeVqb
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/4AxCYLPlCu https://t.co/vEBcbfjuUT

With Russian forces pushing to the city’s limits, Kyiv’s mayor said he was imposing a 36-hour curfew from late Tuesday and that the capital faced a “difficult and dangerous moment.” https://t.co/luPv2e1vyJ
Chernobyl, site of the world’s worst nuclear-power disaster, is now the harrowing scene of 200 trapped, exhausted Ukrainian staffers forced to work nonstop at Russian gunpoint https://t.co/zWRV6WOlal

Wang Jixian, a software programmer from Beijing, is one of the last Chinese nationals still in Ukraine. Instead of fleeing, he is posting videos in what he calls a two-front battle: against the Russian invasion, and against his own compatriots back home. https://t.co/6EywqQoHq0
Wrestling legend Scott Hall, best known for his character “Razor Ramon,” has died at the age of 63 https://t.co/BaN4Ij0sQ2
The Senate confirmed Shalanda Young on Tuesday to be the director of the Office of Management and Budget, the first Black woman to hold the position https://t.co/WQaNR2vqxI

From @WSJopinion: While the world debates and develops sympathy, Ukraine is being destroyed. So I beg our friends in the West: Please give Ukraine the planes and other weapons it needs—now, writes Victor Pinchuk. https://t.co/HrR7s9yLmv
Chernobyl, site of the world’s worst nuclear-power disaster, is now the harrowing scene of 200 trapped, exhausted Ukrainian staffers forced to work nonstop at Russian gunpoint https://t.co/lXXcD3KLY4
President Biden is expected to announce more than $1 billion in new military assistance to the Ukraine government as early as Wednesday, according to U.S. officials https://t.co/KhMoUfn4xT

School-bus cameras are increasingly being used as a traffic-surveillance tool, with local officials saying the purpose is to change the behavior of drivers who fail to stop when buses load or unload students https://t.co/ZaL6E8FMwa

A second journalist working for Fox News was killed covering the war in Ukraine, the network said. Consultant Oleksandra “Sasha” Kuvshynova, 24, had been working with cameraman Pierre Zakrzewski near Kyiv when their vehicle was struck by fire. https://t.co/TrHokFUJUd
The Senate has passed a bill to allow states to make daylight-saving time permanent https://t.co/RI2ogADjVH

Wang Jixian, a software programmer from Beijing, is one of the last Chinese nationals still in Ukraine. Instead of fleeing, he is posting videos in what he calls a two-front battle: against the Russian invasion, and against his own compatriots back home. https://t.co/lCeSmqvKUs

From @WSJopinion: The attempt by Biden to assign blame for the acceleration of prices that began just over a year ago to a war that began just under three weeks ago is remarkable for its cynicism, its dishonesty and its desperation, writes @gerardtbaker https://t.co/MYOALOSUBq

Watch: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping have become close in the past decade, toasting with vodka and exchanging friendship medals. As the West sanctions Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, China could help, but only to a certain extent. https://t.co/C5vifBRfnW
The SEC is investigating the Big Four accounting firms for potential conflicts of interest that could influence their audits, people familiar say https://t.co/AIablJcCHN
A year ago, China’s Xi Jinping appeared unassailable. Since then, thin cracks have emerged in his power. https://t.co/pdccHvdrKz
The woman who burst onto the set of Russia’s most-watched news program Monday evening with an antiwar poster was fined for protest violation https://t.co/gv5irkK8eh
Actress and “Passing” writer-director-producer Rebecca Hall talks about growing as an artist during a time of upheaval and uncertainty. #WSJWomen https://t.co/tMxVXJmEDC

France is ready to grant asylum to the Russian woman who interrupted a live broadcast on Russian state television brandishing a poster against the war in Ukraine, French President Emmanuel Macron said https://t.co/sxYB1MxSUs
Breaking: Fox News cameraman Pierre Zakrzewski was killed on assignment in Ukraine when his vehicle was struck by fire near Kyiv, the network said https://t.co/ACNxwWoBmX
Chernobyl, site of the world’s worst nuclear-power disaster, is now the harrowing scene of 200 trapped, exhausted Ukrainian staffers forced to work nonstop at Russian gunpoint https://t.co/9EkFflUWZg
Saudi Arabia is in talks to price its oil sales to China in yuan, people familiar with the matter said. The move would dent the U.S. dollar's dominance of the oil market. https://t.co/cqwq1xeoYF

Russia's Investigative Committee was probing whether to charge the woman who protested against the war on Russian TV on Monday, Russian state-news agency TASS reported. Human-rights lawyers said the protester's whereabouts are unknown. https://t.co/kXft89oOOg
Oil prices slid below $100 a barrel after China imposed Covid-19 lockdowns, erasing much of the surge since Russia invaded Ukraine https://t.co/cLOfP1D6Aj
